messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Compressed Oblivious Encoding for Homomorphically Encrypted Search

Paper Abstract: Abstract. Fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) enables a simple, attractive framework for secure search. Compared to other secure search systems, no costly setup procedure is necessary; it is sufficient for the client merely to upload the encrypted database to the server. Confidentiality is provided because the server works only on the encrypted query and records. While the search functionality is enabled by the full homomorphism of the encryption scheme. For this reason, researchers have been paying increasing attention to this problem. Since Akavia et al. (CCS 2018) presented a framework for secure search on FHE encrypted data and gave a working implementation called SPiRiT, several more efficient realizations have been proposed. In this paper, we identify the main bottlenecks of this framework and show how to significantly improve the performance of FHE-base secure search. In particular, ‚Ä¢ To retrieve ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell matching items, the existing framework needs to repeat the protocol ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell times sequentially. In our new framework, all matching items are retrieved in parallel in a single protocol execution. ‚Ä¢ The most recent work by Wren et al. (CCS 2020) requires O‚Äã(n)ùëÇùëõO(n) multiplications to compute the first matching index. Our solution requires no homomorphic multiplication, instead using only additions and scalar multiplications to encode all matching indices. ‚Ä¢ Our implementation and experiments show that to fetch 16 matching records, our system gives an 1800X speed-up over the state of the art in fetching the query results resulting in a 26X speed-up for the full search functionality.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Secure Search on Encrypted Data via Multi-Ring Sketch",
        "Setup-Free Secure Search on Encrypted Data: Faster and Post-Processing Free",
        "Communication‚ÄìComputation Trade-offs in PIR",
        "PIR with Compressed Queries and Amortized Query Processing",
        "OptORAMa: Optimal Oblivious RAM",
        "Deterministic and Efficiently Searchable Encryption",
        "Revisiting Leakage Abuse Attacks",
        "Private and Oblivious Set and Multiset Operations",
        "Space/time trade-offs in hash coding with allowable errors",
        "Order-Preserving Symmetric Encryption",
        "Order-Preserving Encryption Revisited: Improved Security Analysis and Alternative Solutions",
        "Public Key Encryption with Keyword Search",
        "A new algorithm for factoring polynomials over finite fields",
        "Highly-Scalable Searchable Symmetric Encryption with Support for Boolean Queries",
        "Structured Encryption and Controlled Disclosure",
        "Optimized Search-and-Compute Circuits and Their Application to Query Evaluation on Encrypted Data",
        "Homomorphic Computation of Edit Distance",
        "Private Information Retrieval",
        "Searchable symmetric encryption: improved definitions and efficient constructions",
        "Somewhat Practical Fully Homomorphic Encryption",
        "Summary cache: a scalable wide-area web cache sharing protocol",
        "SoK: Cryptographically Protected Database Search",
        "How to Play any Mental Game or A Completeness Theorem for Protocols with Honest Majority",
        "Software Protection and Simulation on Oblivious RAMs",
        "Data-oblivious external-memory algorithms for the compaction, selection, and sorting of outsourced data",
        "Breaking Web Applications Built On Top of Encrypted Data",
        "Leakage-Abuse Attacks against Order-Revealing Encryption",
        "Encrypted Databases: New Volume Attacks against Range Queries",
        "Private Large-Scale Databases with Distributed Searchable Symmetric Encryption",
        "Access Pattern disclosure on Searchable Encryption: Ramification, Attack and Mitigation",
        "Generic Attacks on Secure Outsourced Databases",
        "Private Compound Wildcard Queries Using Fully Homomorphic Encryption",
        "HoneyBadgerMPC and AsynchroMix: Practical Asynchronous MPC and its Application to Anonymous Communication",
        "Compressed bloom filters",
        "Property Preserving Symmetric Encryption",
        "Blind Seer: A Scalable Private DBMS",
        "Mitigating Leakage in Secure Cloud-Hosted Data Structures: Volume-Hiding for Multi-Maps via Hashing",
        "POPE: Partial Order Preserving Encoding",
        "P2P Mixing and Unlinkable Bitcoin Transactions",
        "Microsoft SEAL (release 3.6)",
        "Practical Techniques for Searches on Encrypted Data",
        "Sage Mathematics Software (Version 9.2)",
        "PySEAL: A Python wrapper implementation of the SEAL homomorphic encryption library",
        "Oblivious Data Structures",
        "LEAF: A Faster Secure Search Algorithm via Localization, Extraction, and Reconstruction",
        "How to Generate and Exchange Secrets (Extended Abstract)",
        "Secure pattern matching using somewhat homomorphic encryption"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Compressed Oblivious Encoding for Homomorphically Encrypted Search, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
